image.altText: Former NRL player Jarryd Hayne looking unhappy in a street

items.synopsis: The former NRL player remarked "say no more" after the judge read out his sentence for the 2018 sexual assault in Newcastle.

title.children: 'Say no more': Jarryd Hayne sentenced to four years, nine months' jail for sexual assault

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

items.synopsis: Media reports at the time claimed journalist Lisa Wilkinson had been given a clear direction from the ACT Director of Public Prosecutions not to give the speech, which her lawyer disputes.

title.children: ACT's top prosecutor admits he should have done more to correct media reporting of Lisa Wilkinson's Logies speech

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: The stately architecture of budget week follows a similar path each time, but this year it had the Dutton Button added in, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It was all going to script. Then the opposition leader reached for the Dutton Button

image.altText: A young woman with traditional paint on her forehead looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: First Nations women from around Australia have gathered at a historic summit to discuss how to improve gender equality in their communities.

title.children: Historic 'once-in-a-generation' summit in Canberra charts First Nations women's future

image.altText: US Marines compete in a shooting competition in Darwin.

items.synopsis: An ex-US Marine bomb technician set alight in a barbecue explosion is claiming officials knew about a gas leak which led to the incident.

title.children: US Marine burned by exploding barbecue in Darwin sues US, Australian governments for millions

image.altText: Domenic Perre pictured during the 1990s, with slicked back hair, a patterned blue shirt and aviator shades

items.synopsis: The family of Domenic Perre, who died earlier this week less than a year after he was convicted of murdering a detective in the 1994 NCA bombing, is considering making a petition for mercy.

title.children: Bomber's family considers posthumous mercy bid days after his death

image.altText: A close-up photograph of Ricardo Barbaro, a man with short dark hair and a neat beard.

items.synopsis: Ricardo Barbaro will face a third murder trial over the death of Melbourne woman Ellie Price after a jury was discharged to give lawyers time to examine new evidence.

title.children: Ellie Price murder trial abandoned for a second time after new evidence emerges

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Falls across most of the resources sector and a big drop for QBE on its latest earnings update are weighing the ASX down in morning trade. Stay across the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: An Australian super fund's 'alarming' $70m double-up criticised, while the ASX trades flat on Friday

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good afternoon! Emilia from the ABC's business unit here bringing you some developing news on Australia's biggest super fund. AustralianSuper says it's going to refund an estimated $70 million to around 100,000 customers, who were being double charged fees and insurance costs. The fund manages almost $290 billion in retirement savings for 3.1 million Australians. It says it did a review of how it manages multiple accounts, and found it had not eradicated all examples of double up. That means it had members with multiple accounts under the fund who were potentially paying double the fees and insurance. AustralianSuper says it expectes to repay around $650 per impacted person. It says both current and former customers impacted will be contacted in "coming months". "This should not have happened, and we apologise unreservedly to members," its statement said. "The Fund is taking appropriate remediation actions and has self-reported the issue to the regulators." The advocacy group for people with superannuation funds says the revelation by AustralianSuper is "alarming". "Paying extra fees and insurance premiums for more than one account really adds up," Rosie Thomas, Super Consumers Australia's deputy director says. "The Productivity Commission found having unnecessary multiple accounts can leave someone over $50,000 worse off in retirement. "It’s important we fix this problem across the super system, and getting funds to sort out intra-fund consolidation is the first step. "The laws to encourage super funds to get rid of multiple accounts within their own fund are a decade old. "We’ve never seen any public statement or actions from the regulators on this issue. It is alarming that such a major player is only discovering issues now." It now wants a review of all super funds into this issue. Are you an AustralianSuper customer? Have you been told you've got a double up issue? Send me an email on terzon.emilia@abc.net.au This saga from AustralianSuper comes off the back of a general crackdown on fees in the super industry. We just published this list with the best and worst performing funds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AustralianSuper's 'alarming' $70m double-up sparks calls for wider investigation

featuredLink.title: APRA just released its list of underperforming super funds. Is yours on it?

children.content: Good afternoon!
Emilia from the ABC's business unit here bringing you some developing news on Australia's biggest super fund.
AustralianSuper says it's going to refund an estimated $70 million to around 100,000 customers, who were being double charged fees and insurance costs.
The fund manages almost $290 billion in retirement savings for 3.1 million Australians.
It says it did a review of how it manages multiple accounts, and found it had not eradicated all examples of double up.
That means it had members with multiple accounts under the fund who were potentially paying double the fees and insurance.
AustralianSuper says it expectes to repay around $650 per impacted person.
It says both current and former customers impacted will be contacted in "coming months".
"This should not have happened, and we apologise unreservedly to members," its statement said.
"The Fund is taking appropriate remediation actions and has self-reported the issue to the regulators."
The advocacy group for people with superannuation funds says the revelation by AustralianSuper is "alarming".
"Paying extra fees and insurance premiums for more than one account really adds up," Rosie Thomas, Super Consumers Australia's deputy director says.
"The Productivity Commission found having unnecessary multiple accounts can leave someone over $50,000 worse off in retirement.
"It’s important we fix this problem across the super system, and getting funds to sort out intra-fund consolidation is the first step.
"The laws to encourage super funds to get rid of multiple accounts within their own fund are a decade old.
"We’ve never seen any public statement or actions from the regulators on this issue. It is alarming that such a major player is only discovering issues now."
It now wants a review of all super funds into this issue.
Are you an AustralianSuper customer? Have you been told you've got a double up issue? Send me an email on
terzon.emilia@abc.net.au
This saga from AustralianSuper comes off the back of a general crackdown on fees in the super industry. We just published this list with the best and worst performing funds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This short statement out today from Medibank: "Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022. "The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation. "Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures." This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank facing privacy breach investigation as customers seek compensation

featuredLink.title: Class action firms join forces to litigate Medibank breach

children.content: This short statement out today from Medibank:

"Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022.
"The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation.

"Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures."
This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with
Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has taken action against three telcos for allowing the misuse, or potential misuse, of sender IDs. "ACMA investigations found Sinch Australia Pty Ltd (Sinch), Infobip Information Technology Pty Ltd (Infobip) and Phone Card Selector Pty Ltd (Phone Card) allowed SMS to be sent using text-based sender IDs without sufficient checks to ensure they were being used legitimately. "The ACMA found Infobip allowed 103,146 non-compliant SMS to be sent, which included scams impersonating well known Australian road toll companies. Sinch allowed 14,291 non-complaint SMS, which included Medicare and Australia Post impersonation scams. "Phone Card was also found to have inadequate systems in place to comply with the rules, however there is no evidence that scammers exploited the opportunities it created. "Text-based sender IDs can be used by scammers to pose as legitimate organisations such as government agencies, banks and road toll companies. Under the Reducing Scam Calls and Scam SMS Code, Australian telcos must obtain evidence from customers that they have a legitimate reason to use text-based sender IDs (such as business names) in SMS." Despite the tough talk, the penalties for the breaches are … nothing. "The ACMA has given Sinch and Infobip formal directions to comply with the obligations, the strongest enforcement action available for code breaches. Phone Card has been given a formal warning. "Combating SMS and identity theft phone scams is an ACMA compliance priority and telcos may face penalties of up to $250,000 for breaching ACMA directions to comply with the code."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telcos pinged over fake sender ID scam texts

children.content: The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has taken action against three telcos for allowing the misuse, or potential misuse, of sender IDs.

"ACMA investigations found Sinch Australia Pty Ltd (Sinch), Infobip Information Technology Pty Ltd (Infobip) and Phone Card Selector Pty Ltd (Phone Card) allowed SMS to be sent using text-based sender IDs without sufficient checks to ensure they were being used legitimately.

"The ACMA found Infobip allowed 103,146 non-compliant SMS to be sent, which included scams impersonating well known Australian road toll companies. Sinch allowed 14,291 non-complaint SMS, which included Medicare and Australia Post impersonation scams.
"Phone Card was also found to have inadequate systems in place to comply with the rules, however there is no evidence that scammers exploited the opportunities it created.

"Text-based sender IDs can be used by scammers to pose as legitimate organisations such as government agencies, banks and road toll companies. Under the Reducing Scam Calls and Scam SMS Code, Australian telcos must obtain evidence from customers that they have a legitimate reason to use text-based sender IDs (such as business names) in SMS."
Despite the tough talk, the penalties for the breaches are … nothing.
"The ACMA has given Sinch and Infobip formal directions to comply with the obligations, the strongest enforcement action available for code breaches. Phone Card has been given a formal warning.
"Combating SMS and identity theft phone scams is an ACMA compliance priority and telcos may face penalties of up to $250,000 for breaching ACMA directions to comply with the code."

image.altText: Peter Hollingworth

items.synopsis: Former governor-general Peter Hollingworth says he has given up his permission to officiate as an Anglican priest, after a church investigation last month found he committed misconduct by knowingly allowing paedophiles to remain in the church.

title.children: Peter Hollingworth says he will no longer officiate as Anglican priest after church investigation finding

image.altText: A female Aedes aegypti mosquito bites someone's skin.

items.synopsis: Health officials say there have now been four cases, inlcuding two fatal, of the disease this year in the Northern Territory compared to two cases in the previous five years.

title.children: Infant dies of Murray Valley encephalitis in NT, as officials issue warning following spike in cases

image.altText: Lara Alexander and John Tucker looking at each other.

items.synopsis: Concerns over a contentious $715 million stadium and the government's priorities have pushed two Tasmanian MPs to quit the Liberal Party and sit as independents, ending Premier Jeremy Rockliff's majority.

title.children: Anger over Hobart AFL stadium sinks Tasmania's government into minority as MPs quit party

image.altText: John Pesutto and Moira Deeming in a composite image.

items.synopsis: Rebel Victorian MP Moira Deeming has been expelled from the parliamentary Liberal Party after a meeting of MPs this morning, with Renee Heath ditched as partyroom secretary.

title.children: Victorian Liberal leader labels expulsion of MP Moira Deeming a 'turning point' in party's reform

image.altText: Justin Tkatchenko with PNG's governor general Sir Bob Bofeng Dadae in formal suits.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister James Marape asks the people of Papua New Guinea to "forgive" the country's foreign minister after his apology for his "primitive animals" comments.

title.children: 'Unsavoury use of words': PNG's PM says he was offended by foreign minister's 'primitive animals' comment

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: Despite increased rental assistance measures in Tuesday's budget, calls to cap rents are growing louder, with economists saying that step has been successful overseas, however, analysts warn it may make the housing crisis worse.

title.children: 'We need intervention': Renters say price caps are needed to help keep a roof over their heads

image.altText: A red Mercedes Benz with a crumpled front and missing roof

items.synopsis: The impact of the crash was so severe the engine was ripped from the red Mercedes Benz and landed some distance away, South Australia Police said.

title.children: Murray Bridge woman airlifted to hospital after crashing suspected stolen luxury car

image.altText: A teenage girl in sports gear concentrates as she grasps and swings between two "X"-shaped plates hanging from the ceiling.

items.synopsis: Abbey Cutts has won the right to represent Australia in two international ninja championships in the United States next month. But first she has to get there.

title.children: Teenager Abbey Cutts practices for hours on a ninja course in her backyard. Now she's heading to world finals

image.altText: Machinery in a factory including two large silver vat-like parts.

items.synopsis: Bioelektra Australia has entered into voluntary administration after it was engaged to use Polish technology to divert 90 per cent of a NSW council's waste from landfill.

title.children: Calls for answers after recycling company that promised a 'revolution' collapses

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff appears to be in thought, surrounded by his colleagues.

items.synopsis: Just yesterday, the Tasmanian government was sailing along relatively smoothly as the only remaining Liberal government in the country, but two bombshell resignations have changed all that, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The Tasmanian premier's $715 million stadium is costing him more than money

image.altText: A man with a backwards cap holding a football.

items.synopsis: Daniel Hayes was forging a path to a dream career in the AFL 17 years ago — but after leaving the Demons without playing a game, the small forward was left grappling with feelings few understood.

title.children: When Daniel Hayes disappeared from the AFL, he didn't share his pain — now he is suing his junior coach

image.altText: Soldiers launch missiles hidden by camouflage tents and surrounded by trees

items.synopsis: Moscow reacts after Russian military bloggers report Ukrainian advances north and south of the fiercely contested city of Bakhmut in the east of Ukraine, while some US Senators accuse the Pentagon of undermining a war crimes probe by refusing to share information with the ICC.

title.children: Russia denies reports of Ukrainian breakthroughs along front lines near Bakhmut

image.altText: A patch of grey rock exposed on a green mountain with a village of houses at the bottom of the mountain

items.synopsis: History is repeating itself in the village of Brienz as residents are ordered to abandon their tiny mountain home.

title.children: This tiny Swiss village is at risk of being hit by a wall of rocks as history repeats

image.altText: A man sitting behind a desk, leaning back in his chair and scratching his chin, mid-conversation.

items.synopsis: Michael Gunner has been cleared of alleged political interference over the decision to charge former Northern Territory police officer Zachary Rolfe with the murder of Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: Former chief minister cleared of alleged political interference in Rolfe murder charge

image.altText: Frank Hu holds a phone to his ear, dressed in a green jumper.

items.synopsis: A serial rapist will spend decades behind bars for spiking the drinks of female colleagues, sexually abusing them while they were passed out and posting images of the attacks online.

title.children: Man who offered female colleagues drugged drinks before raping them jailed for 'cold, calculated' attacks

image.altText: A man sings while sitting in a car with the headlights on, on stage during rehearsals for the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.synopsis: For the past eight years, Australia has been welcomed into the glitter-laced arms of Eurovision, but this may come to an end very soon.

title.children: This could be our last year competing in Eurovision, but why is Australia in Eurovision in the first place?

image.altText: Short sleeved dark navy police t-shirt, viewed from back of officer in uniform

items.synopsis: Emergency services were contacted when a visiting relative attempted to see the man and was allegedly told he was in hospital.

title.children: 'Mummified' body found in Gold Coast home where two people lived

image.altText: Two people standing in front of a pizza store, with the logo visible in the background.

items.synopsis: The manager of a regional Victorian pizza shop is calling out racism after several incidents which she believes targeted Pakistani staff.

title.children: 'This is their home': Takeaway worker's call to stand up against racism

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump claps his hand together at rally in Manchester, New Hampshire.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump signals he will appeal against a jury's decision to find him liable for sexual abuse and defamation, a day after joking about the case during a controversial CNN broadcast.

title.children: Trump lodges appeal against sexual abuse finding as CNN grapples with town hall fallout

image.altText: Composite image of Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka with birthday cakes presented to them at the Madrid Open.

items.synopsis: The chief executive of the Madrid Open apologises after the women's doubles finalists were not allowed to address fans after their match and says it will never happen again, but the tournament is under fire for other issues regarding inequality.

title.children: 'Couldn't be more accurate': What two birthday cakes say about top tennis tournament's treatment of women

image.altText: A woman stands with a handwritten sign in front of a crowd in Federation Square.

items.synopsis: Members of the Pakistani diaspora, chanting "this terrorism has a uniform behind it", protest in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne following the arrest of former prime minister Imran Khan in Islamabad this week.

title.children: Imran Khan's Australian supporters take to the streets to denounce military and 'injustice'

image.altText: An open cut mine pit at Burton coal mine near Moranbah.

items.synopsis: The Isaac River Mine in central Queensland has been flagged for approval if a vulnerable snake can be protected, but an environmental group says people who voted in favour of climate action have a right to feel betrayed.

title.children: 'A right to feel betrayed': New coal mine flagged for approval by federal government

image.altText: A composite image of the headless ram and the updated version.

items.synopsis: The tiny town of Narrawong was shocked when a mighty wooden ram that guards the district was callously decapitated in February. Then Chainsaw Kev came to the rescue.

title.children: How 'Chainsaw Kev' came out of the woodwork to fix south-west Victoria's decapitated ram sculpture

image.altText: A group of people is pictured sitting on trop of a train, some have their legs hanging over the side.

items.synopsis: Thousands of migrants in Mexico have been clambering onto dangerous freight trains rumbling northward in a scramble to reach the US border by the time the United States ends a tough migration policy.

title.children: Migrants risk life and limb to jump Mexico trains in rush to US border as Title 42 draws to an end
